title: Pete Athas
text:
Peter Garrett Athas (September 15, 1946 – June 28, 2015) was an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a> who played six seasons in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> for the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a>, <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>, <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a> and the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Tennessee">University of Tennessee</a>.
Early years.
Athas attended <a href="Miami%20Edison%20High%20School">Miami Edison High School</a>, before he <a href="Walk-on%20%28sports%29">walked on</a> to the <a href="University%20of%20Tennessee">University of Tennessee</a>.
He would never <a href="Letterman%20%28sports%29">letter</a> in <a href="American%20football">football</a> with the Volunteers, after playing in just 2 games for the freshman team (freshmen weren’t eligible until 1972) and dropping out of college. He also attended <a href="Miami%20Dade%20College">Miami-Dade Junior College</a>.
Professional career.
Orlando Panthers (CFL).
Athas was signed by the <a href="Orlando%20Panthers">Orlando Panthers</a> of the <a href="Continental%20Football%20League">Continental Football League</a> in 1967. The next year he was named the starter at <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a>, receiving All-Star honors after leading the league with a record 10 interceptions.
In 1969, he led the league again in interceptions with 9 (one returned for a touchdown). Counting also pre-season and post-season games, he posted a total of 27 interceptions in 34 games.
Dallas Cowboys.
Entering the <a href="1970%20NFL%20draft">1970 NFL draft</a>, the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> were looking to improve the talent level of their defensive backfield, so they proceeded to trade for <a href="All-Pro">All-Pro</a> <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a> <a href="Herb%20Adderley">Herb Adderley</a> and selected 5 <a href="defensive%20back">defensive back</a>s, with Athas being selected in the tenth round (257th) overall.
As a rookie, he was being tried out at <a href="free%20safety">free safety</a> and was moving up the depth chart, until getting into a fight with teammate <a href="Reggie%20Rucker">Reggie Rucker</a>, which caused him a broken jaw and lost time because of the injury. He was waived before the start of the season.
Norfolk Neptunes (ACFL).
Athas signed with the <a href="Norfolk%20Neptunes">Norfolk Neptunes</a> of the <a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Football%20League">Atlantic Coast Football League</a> for their 1970 season.
New York Giants.
Athas was signed as a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a> by the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a> in <a href="1971%20NFL%20season">1971</a>, reuniting with defensive coordinator <a href="Jim%20Garrett">Jim Garrett</a>, who was his head coach with the <a href="Orlando%20Panthers">Orlando Panthers</a>. He earned a starting role as a <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a> and a <a href="punt%20returner">punt returner</a>. He tied for the team lead in interceptions (4) in <a href="1972%20NFL%20season">1972</a> and led the team with 5 interceptions the next year. He was released on September 10, <a href="1975%20NFL%20season">1975</a>.
Cleveland Browns.
On September 18, <a href="1975%20NFL%20season">1975</a>, he signed as a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a> with the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>. he was named the starter at <a href="free%20safety">free safety</a>, until committing critical errors (two fumbled punts and an unsportsmanlike penalty) in a 23–7 loss against the <a href="Washington%20Redskins">Washington Redskins</a>, which led to his surprising release on October 28.
Minnesota Vikings.
Athas signed with the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a> after his release and was used as a reserve <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a>. He was cut before the start of the <a href="1976%20NFL%20season">1976 season</a>.
New Orleans Saints.
On September 15, <a href="1976%20NFL%20season">1976</a>, the <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a> signed him as a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a>, to use him as a <a href="punt%20returner">punt returner</a> and reserve <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a>, after <a href="Clarence%20Chapman">Clarence Chapman</a> was injured. He finished with the second most <a href="punt%20return">punt return</a>s (35) in team history at the time. He was waived on April 5, <a href="1977%20NFL%20season">1977</a>.
Personal life.
Athas resided in <a href="Miami%2C%20Florida">Miami, Florida</a>, until his death from <a href="lymphoma">lymphoma</a> on June 28, 2015.
